graphwar.nn¶

graphwar.nn.layers¶

activations

Sequential

A modified torch.nn.Sequential which can take multiple inputs.

GCNConv

SGConv

SSGConv

DAGNNConv

Deep Adaptive Graph Neural Network in Towards Deeper Graph Neural Networks <https://arxiv.org/abs/2007.09296>

TAGConv

MedianConv

RobustConv

DropEdge

DropEdge: Sampling edge using a uniform distribution.

DropPath

DropPath: path-wise structured dropout.

AdaptiveConv

The adaptive message passing layer from the paper "Graph Neural Networks with Adaptive Residual", NeurIPS 2021

ElasticConv

The elastic message passing layer from the paper "Elastic Graph Neural Networks", ICML 2021

SoftMedianConv

SATConv

class Sequential(*args, loc=0)[source]¶

A modified torch.nn.Sequential which can take multiple inputs.

Example

>>> import torch
>>> from graphwar.nn.layers import Sequential, GCNConv
>>>
>>> edge_index = ... # size [2, M]
>>> x = torch.randn(5, 20)

>>> conv1 = GCNConv(20, 50)
>>> conv2 = GCNConv(50, 5)
>>> dropout1 = torch.nn.Dropout(0.5)
>>> dropout2 = torch.nn.Dropout(0.6)

>>> # Case 1: standard usage
>>> sequential = Sequential(dropout1, conv1, dropout2, conv2)
>>> sequential(x, edge_index)
tensor([[ 0.6738, -0.9032, -0.9628,  0.0670,  0.0252],
    [ 0.4909, -1.2430, -0.6029,  0.0510,  0.2107],
    [ 0.6338, -0.2760, -0.9112, -0.3197,  0.2689],
    [ 0.4909, -1.2430, -0.6029,  0.0510,  0.2107],
    [ 0.3876, -0.6385, -0.5521, -0.2753,  0.6713]], grad_fn=<AddBackward0>)

>>> # which is equivalent to:
>>> h1 = dropout1(x)
>>> h2 = conv1(h1, edge_index)
>>> h3 = dropout2(h2)
>>> h4 = conv2(h3, edge_index)

>>> # Case 2: with keyword argument
>>> sequential(x, edge_index, edge_weight=torch.ones(20))
tensor([[ 0.6738, -0.9032, -0.9628,  0.0670,  0.0252],
    [ 0.4909, -1.2430, -0.6029,  0.0510,  0.2107],
    [ 0.6338, -0.2760, -0.9112, -0.3197,  0.2689],
    [ 0.4909, -1.2430, -0.6029,  0.0510,  0.2107],
    [ 0.3876, -0.6385, -0.5521, -0.2753,  0.6713]], grad_fn=<AddBackward0>)

>>> # which is equivalent to:
>>> h1 = dropout1(x)
>>> h2 = conv1(x, edge_index, edge_weight=torch.ones(20))
>>> h3 = dropout2(h2)
>>> h4 = conv2(x, edge_index, edge_weight=torch.ones(20))

Note

  • The argument loc must be specified as the location of feature input x,

which would walk through the whole layers.

  • The usage of keyword argument must be matched with that of the layers

with more than one arguments required.

forward(*inputs, **kwargs)[source]¶

Defines the computation performed at every call.

Should be overridden by all subclasses.

Note

Although the recipe for forward pass needs to be defined within this function, one should call the Module instance afterwards instead of this since the former takes care of running the registered hooks while the latter silently ignores them.

training: bool¶

graphwar.nn.models¶

GCN

Graph Convolution Network (GCN)

SGC

Simplifying Graph Convolution layer from paper Simplifying Graph Convolutional Networks.

SSGC

Simple Spectra Graph Convolution Network from paper `Simple Spectral Graph Convolution

GAT

Graph Attention Network (GAT)

APPNP

Approximated personalized propagation of neural predictions (APPNP)

DAGNN

Deep Adaptive Graph Neural Networks.

JKNet

Graph Convolution Network with Jumping knowledge (JKNet)

TAGCN

Topological Adaptive Graph Convolutional Networks (TAGCN)

MedianGCN

Graph Convolution Network (GCN) with median aggragation

RobustGCN

Robust Graph Convolution Network (RobustGCN).

AirGNN

Graph Neural Networks with Adaptive residual.

ElasticGNN

Graph Neural Networks with elastic message passing.

SoftMedianGCN

Graph Convolution Network (GCN) with Soft Median Aggregation

SimPGCN

Similarity Preserving Graph Convolution Network (SimPGCN).

GNNGUARD

Graph Convolution Network (GCN) with GNNGUARD

SAT

class GCN(in_channels: int, out_channels: int, hids: list = [16], acts: list = ['relu'], dropout: float = 0.5, bn: bool = False, normalize: bool = True, bias: bool = True)[source]¶

Graph Convolution Network (GCN)

Example

# GCN with one hidden layer >>> model = GCN(100, 10) # GCN with two hidden layers >>> model = GCN(100, 10, hids=[32, 16], acts=[‘relu’, ‘elu’]) # GCN with two hidden layers, without activation at the first layer >>> model = GCN(100, 10, hids=[32, 16], acts=[None, ‘relu’])

Should be overridden by all subclasses.

Note

Although the recipe for forward pass needs to be defined within this function, one should call the Module instance afterwards instead of this since the former takes care of running the registered hooks while the latter silently ignores them.

training: bool¶
class SGC(in_channels, out_channels, hids: list = [], acts: list = [], dropout: float = 0.0, K: int = 2, bn: bool = False, bias: bool = True, cached: bool = True)[source]¶

Simplifying Graph Convolution layer from paper Simplifying Graph Convolutional Networks.

Example

# SGC model without hidden layers (by default) >>> model = SGC(100, 10) # SGC with one hidden layers >>> model = SGC(100, 10, hids=[16], acts=[‘relu’])

training: bool¶
class SSGC(in_channels, out_channels, hids: list = [], acts: list = [], dropout: float = 0.0, K: int = 5, alpha: float = 0.1, bn: bool = False, bias: bool = True, cached: bool = True)[source]¶
Simple Spectra Graph Convolution Network from paper `Simple Spectral Graph Convolution

<https://openreview.net/forum?id=CYO5T-YjWZV>`__.

Example

# SSGC model without hidden layers (by default) >>> model = SSGC(100, 10) # SSGC with one hidden layers >>> model = SSGC(100, 10, hids=[16], acts=[‘relu’])

training: bool¶
class GAT(in_channels: int, out_channels: int, hids: list = [8], num_heads: list = [8], acts: list = ['elu'], dropout: float = 0.6, bias: bool = True, bn: bool = False, includes=['num_heads'])[source]¶

Graph Attention Network (GAT)

Example

# GAT with one hidden layer >>> model = GAT(100, 10) # GAT with two hidden layers >>> model = GAT(100, 10, hids=[32, 16], num_heads=[8, 8], acts=[‘relu’, ‘elu’]) # GAT with two hidden layers, without activation at the first layer >>> model = GAT(100, 10, hids=[32, 16], num_heads=[8, 8], acts=[None, ‘elu’])

References

  • Paper: https://arxiv.org/abs/1710.10903

  • Author’s code: https://github.com/PetarV-/GAT

  • Pytorch implementation: https://github.com/Diego999/pyGAT

class JKNet(in_channels: int, out_channels: int, hids: list = [16, 16, 16], acts: list = ['relu', 'relu', 'relu'], dropout: float = 0.5, mode: str = 'cat', bn: bool = False, bias: bool = True)[source]¶

Graph Convolution Network with Jumping knowledge (JKNet)

Example

# JKNet with five hidden layers >>> model = JKNet(100, 10, hids=[16]*5)

class RobustGCN(in_channels: int, out_channels: int, hids: list = [32], acts: list = ['relu'], dropout: float = 0.5, bn: bool = False, bias: bool = True, gamma: float = 1.0)[source]¶

Robust Graph Convolution Network (RobustGCN).

Example

# RobustGCN with one hidden layer >>> model = RobustGCN(100, 10) # RobustGCN with two hidden layers >>> model = RobustGCN(100, 10, hids=[32, 16], acts=[‘relu’, ‘elu’]) # RobustGCN with two hidden layers, without activation at the first layer >>> model = RobustGCN(100, 10, hids=[32, 16], acts=[None, ‘relu’])

Note

please make sure hids and acts are both list or tuple and len(hids)==len(acts).

Although the recipe for forward pass needs to be defined within this function, one should call the Module instance afterwards instead of this since the former takes care of running the registered hooks while the latter silently ignores them.

training: bool¶
class SimPGCN(in_channels: int, out_channels: int, hids: list = [64], acts: list = [None], dropout: float = 0.5, bn: bool = False, bias: bool = True, gamma: float = 0.01)[source]¶

Similarity Preserving Graph Convolution Network (SimPGCN).

Example

# SimPGCN with one hidden layer >>> model = SimPGCN(100, 10) # SimPGCN with two hidden layers >>> model = SimPGCN(100, 10, hids=[32, 16], acts=[‘relu’, ‘elu’]) # SimPGCN with two hidden layers, without activation at the first layer >>> model = SimPGCN(100, 10, hids=[32, 16], acts=[None, ‘relu’])

cache_clear()[source]¶
forward(x, edge_index, edge_weight=None)[source]¶

Defines the computation performed at every call.

Should be overridden by all subclasses.

Note

Although the recipe for forward pass needs to be defined within this function, one should call the Module instance afterwards instead of this since the former takes care of running the registered hooks while the latter silently ignores them.

training: bool¶
class GNNGUARD(in_channels: int, out_channels: int, hids: list = [16], acts: list = ['relu'], dropout: float = 0.5, bn: bool = False, normalize: bool = True, bias: bool = True)[source]¶

Graph Convolution Network (GCN) with GNNGUARD

Example

# GNNGUARD with one hidden layer >>> model = GNNGUARD(100, 10) # GNNGUARD with two hidden layers >>> model = GNNGUARD(100, 10, hids=[32, 16], acts=[‘relu’, ‘elu’]) # GNNGUARD with two hidden layers, without activation at the first layer >>> model = GNNGUARD(100, 10, hids=[32, 16], acts=[None, ‘relu’])
